speech.line: What, the chain?

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: No, no, the bell, ’tis time that I were gone:
It was two ere I left him, and now the clock strikes one.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: The hours come back! That did I never hear.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: O yes, if any hour meet a sergeant, ’a turns back for very fear.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: As if Time were in debt! How fondly dost thou reason!

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Time is a very bankrout and owes more than he’s worth to season.
Nay, he’s a thief too: have you not heard men say,
That Time comes stealing on by night and day?
If ’a be in debt and theft, and a sergeant in the way,
Hath he not reason to turn back an hour in a day?

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Go, Dromio, there’s the money, bear it straight,
And bring thy master home immediately.
Come, sister, I am press’d down with conceit—
Conceit, my comfort and my injury.

scene.scenepersonae: (Antipholus of Syracuse, Dromio of Syracuse, Courtezan)
scene.scenedescription: Antipholus of Syracuse, having been in the market place, is surprised to be greeted by all. Dromio of Syracuse enters with the money to bail him, but Antipholus knows nothing of any arrest. He asks about his ship, and Dromio tells him, saying he told him a short time before. The courtesan enters, sees the chain, and asks for it in exchange for the ring she gave Antipholus of Ephesus, according to their bargain. Antipholus of Syracuse thinks she is a witch, and will have nothing to do with her. Cheated out of her ring, she thinks Antipholus of Syracuse is crazy, and goes to tell the wife of Antipholus of Ephesus she was cheated by him.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: There’s not a man I meet but doth salute me
As if I were their well-acquainted friend,
And every one doth call me by my name:
Some tender money to me, some invite me;
Some other give me thanks for kindnesses;
Some offer me commodities to buy.
Even now a tailor call’d me in his shop,
And show’d me silks that he had bought for me,
And therewithal took measure of my body.
Sure these are but imaginary wiles,
And Lapland sorcerers inhabit here.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Master, here’s the gold you sent me for. What, have you got the picture of old Adam new apparell’d?

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: What gold is this? What Adam dost thou mean?

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Not that Adam that kept the Paradise, but that Adam that keeps the prison; he that goes in the calve’s-skin that was kill’d for the Prodigal; he that came behind you, sir, like an evil angel, and bid you forsake your liberty.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: I understand thee not.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: No? Why, ’tis a plain case: he that went like a base-viol in a case of leather; the man, sir, that when gentlemen are tir’d, gives them a sob and ’rests them; he, sir, that takes pity on decay’d men and gives them suits of durance; he that sets up his rest to do more exploits with his mace than a morris-pike.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: What, thou mean’st an officer?

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Ay, sir, the sergeant of the band: he that brings any man to answer it that breaks his band; one that thinks a man always going to bed and says, “God give you good rest!”

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: Well, sir, there rest in your foolery. Is there any ships puts forth tonight? May we be gone?

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Why, sir, I brought you word an hour since that the bark Expedition put forth tonight, and then were you hind’red by the sergeant to tarry for the hoy Delay. Here are the angels that you sent for to deliver you.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: The fellow is distract, and so am I,
And here we wander in illusions:
Some blessed power deliver us from hence!

speech.speaker: COUR.
speech.line: Well met, well met, Master Antipholus.
I see, sir, you have found the goldsmith now.
Is that the chain you promis’d me today?

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: Sathan, avoid, I charge thee tempt me not.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Master, is this Mistress Sathan?

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: It is the devil.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Nay, she is worse, she is the devil’s dam, and here she comes in the habit of a light wench; and thereof comes that the wenches say, “God damn me,” that’s as much to say, “God make me a light wench.” It is written, they appear to men like angels of light, light is an effect of fire, and fire will burn: ergo, light wenches will burn. Come not near her.

speech.speaker: COUR.
speech.line: Your man and you are marvellous merry, sir.
Will you go with me? We’ll mend our dinner here.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Master, if you do, expect spoon-meat, or bespeak a long spoon.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: Why, Dromio?

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Marry, he must have a long spoon that must eat with the devil.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: Avoid then, fiend, what tell’st thou me of supping?
Thou art, as you are all, a sorceress:
I conjure thee to leave me and be gone.

speech.speaker: COUR.
speech.line: Give me the ring of mine you had at dinner,
Or, for my diamond, the chain you promis’d,
And I’ll be gone, sir, and not trouble you.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Some devils ask but the parings of one’s nail,
A rush, a hair, a drop of blood, a pin,
A nut, a cherry-stone;
But she, more covetous, would have a chain.
Master, be wise, and if you give it her,
The devil will shake her chain, and fright us with it.

speech.speaker: COUR.
speech.line: I pray you, sir, my ring, or else the chain;
I hope you do not mean to cheat me so?

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: Avaunt, thou witch! Come, Dromio, let us go.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: “Fly pride,” says the peacock: mistress, that you know.

speech.speaker: COUR.
speech.line: Now out of doubt Antipholus is mad,
Else would he never so demean himself.
A ring he hath of mine worth forty ducats,
And for the same he promis’d me a chain:
Both one and other he denies me now.
The reason that I gather he is mad,
Besides this present instance of his rage,
Is a mad tale he told today at dinner,
Of his own doors being shut against his entrance.
Belike his wife, acquainted with his fits,
On purpose shut the doors against his way.
My way is now to hie home to his house,
And tell his wife that, being lunatic,
He rush’d into my house, and took perforce
My ring away. This course I fittest choose,
For forty ducats is too much to lose.

scene.scenepersonae: (Antipholus of Ephesus, Officer, Dromio of Ephesus, Adriana, Luciana, Courtezan, Pinch, Antipholus of Syracuse, Dromio of Syracuse)
scene.scenedescription: Dromio of Ephesus with a rope meets Antipholus of Ephesus with the officers, delivers the rope, and receives a beating for not bringing money, while he denies he was sent for any. Adriana, Luciana, the courtesan, and the schoolmaster Pinch enter, and Pinch attempts to exorcise Antipholus, receiving a beating for his pains. Antipholus, seconded by Dromio, tells a story of being shut out of his house at dinner, though Adriana says he dined with her. Adriana, seconded by Luciana, tells how she gave the money to Dromio (of Syracuse) but Dromio of Ephesus denies ever having got it. Master and servant are tied up as madmen. Antipholus accuses Adriana of having Pinch with her when she shut him out. Antipholus and Dromio are taken away, after Adriana promises to discharge the debt. Inquiring of the officer, Adriana finds that the money was for the chain, which the courtesan claims was promised her in exchange for her ring. Antipholus and Dromio of Syracuse enter with drawn swords and the others flee, thinking they are loose again and out to kill them. Antipholus and Dromio are glad that witches fear swords, but Antipholus says he will not stay any longer in town, though Dromio feels except for the fat woman claiming him he would be willing to stay and turn witch himself.
scene.stagedir: Enter Antipholus of Ephesus with the Officer.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Fear me not, man, I will not break away;
I’ll give thee, ere I leave thee, so much money,
To warrant thee, as I am ’rested for.
My wife is in a wayward mood today,
And will not lightly trust the messenger,
That I should be attach’d in Ephesus;
I tell you, ’twill sound harshly in her ears.
speech.stagedir: Enter Dromio of Ephesus with a rope’s end.
speech.line: Here comes my man: I think he brings the money.
How now, sir? Have you that I sent you for?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Here’s that, I warrant you, will pay them all.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: But where’s the money?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Why, sir, I gave the money for the rope.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Five hundred ducats, villain, for a rope?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: I’ll serve you, sir, five hundred at the rate.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: To what end did I bid thee hie thee home?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: To a rope’s end, sir, and to that end am I return’d.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: And to that end, sir, I will welcome you.

speech.speaker: OFF.
speech.line: Good sir, be patient.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Nay, ’tis for me to be patient: I am in adversity.

speech.speaker: OFF.
speech.line: Good now, hold thy tongue.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Nay, rather persuade him to hold his hands.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Thou whoreson, senseless villain!

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: I would I were senseless, sir, that I might not feel your blows.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Thou art sensible in nothing but blows, and so is an ass.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: I am an ass indeed; you may prove it by my long ears. I have serv’d him from the hour of my nativity to this instant, and have nothing at his hands for my service but blows. When I am cold, he heats me with beating; when I am warm, he cools me with beating. I am wak’d with it when I sleep, rais’d with it when I sit, driven out of doors with it when I go from home, welcom’d home with it when I return; nay, I bear it on my shoulders, as a beggar wont her brat; and I think when he hath lam’d me, I shall beg with it from door to door.

scene.stagedir: Enter Adriana, Luciana, Courtezan, and a schoolmaster call’d Pinch.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Come go along, my wife is coming yonder.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Mistress, respice finem, respect your end, or rather, the prophecy like the parrot, “beware the rope’s end.”

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Wilt thou still talk?

speech.speaker: COUR.
speech.line: How say you now? Is not your husband mad?

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: His incivility confirms no less.
Good Doctor Pinch, you are a conjurer,
Establish him in his true sense again,
And I will please you what you will demand.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Alas, how fiery, and how sharp, he looks!

speech.speaker: COUR.
speech.line: Mark, how he trembles in his ecstasy!

speech.speaker: PINCH.
speech.line: Give me your hand, and let me feel your pulse.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: There is my hand, and let it feel your ear.

speech.speaker: PINCH.
speech.line: I charge thee, Sathan, hous’d within this man,
To yield possession to my holy prayers,
And to thy state of darkness hie thee straight:
I conjure thee by all the saints in heaven!

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Peace, doting wizard, peace! I am not mad.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: O that thou wert not, poor distressed soul!

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: You minion, you, are these your customers?
Did this companion with the saffron face
Revel and feast it at my house today,
Whilst upon me the guilty doors were shut,
And I denied to enter in my house?

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: O husband, God doth know you din’d at home,
Where would you had remain’d until this time,
Free from these slanders and this open shame.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Din’d at home? Thou villain, what sayest thou?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Sir, sooth to say, you did not dine at home.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Were not my doors lock’d up, and I shut out?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Perdie, your doors were lock’d, and you shut out.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: And did not she herself revile me there?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Sans fable, she herself revil’d you there.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Did not her kitchen maid rail, taunt, and scorn me?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Certes she did, the kitchen vestal scorn’d you.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: And did not I in rage depart from thence?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: In verity you did, my bones bears witness,
That since have felt the vigor of his rage.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Is’t good to soothe him in these contraries?

speech.speaker: PINCH.
speech.line: It is no shame; the fellow finds his vein,
And yielding to him, humors well his frenzy.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Thou hast suborn’d the goldsmith to arrest me.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Alas, I sent you money to redeem you,
By Dromio here, who came in haste for it.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Money by me? Heart and good will you might,
But surely, master, not a rag of money.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Went’st not thou to her for a purse of ducats?

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: He came to me, and I deliver’d it.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: And I am witness with her that she did.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: God and the rope-maker bear me witness
That I was sent for nothing but a rope!

speech.speaker: PINCH.
speech.line: Mistress, both man and master is possess’d:
I know it by their pale and deadly looks.
They must be bound and laid in some dark room.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Say wherefore didst thou lock me forth today?
And why dost thou deny the bag of gold?

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: I did not, gentle husband, lock thee forth.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: And, gentle master, I receiv’d no gold;
But I confess, sir, that we were lock’d out.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Dissembling villain, thou speak’st false in both.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Dissembling harlot, thou art false in all,
And art confederate with a damned pack
To make a loathsome abject scorn of me;
But with these nails I’ll pluck out these false eyes
That would behold in me this shameful sport.

scene.stagedir: Enter three or four, and offer to bind him; he strives.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: O, bind him, bind him, let him not come near me.

speech.speaker: PINCH.
speech.line: More company! The fiend is strong within him.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Ay me, poor man, how pale and wan he looks!

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: What, will you murder me? Thou jailer, thou,
I am thy prisoner. Wilt thou suffer them
To make a rescue?

speech.speaker: OFF.
speech.line: Masters, let him go:
He is my prisoner, and you shall not have him.

speech.speaker: PINCH.
speech.line: Go bind this man, for he is frantic too.

scene.stagedir: They offer to bind Dromio of Ephesus.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: What wilt thou do, thou peevish officer?
Hast thou delight to see a wretched man
Do outrage and displeasure to himself?

speech.speaker: OFF.
speech.line: He is my prisoner; if I let him go,
The debt he owes will be requir’d of me.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: I will discharge thee ere I go from thee:
Bear me forthwith unto his creditor,
And knowing how the debt grows, I will pay it.
Good Master Doctor, see him safe convey’d
Home to my house. O most unhappy day!

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: O most unhappy strumpet!

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Master, I am here ent’red in bond for you.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Out on thee, villain, wherefore dost thou mad me?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Will you be bound for nothing? Be mad, good master,
Cry “The devil!”

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: God help, poor souls, how idlely do they talk!

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Go bear him hence. Sister, go you with me.
speech.stagedir: Exeunt Manent Officer, Adriana, Luciana, Courtezan.
speech.line: Say now, whose suit is he arrested at?

speech.speaker: OFF.
speech.line: One Angelo, a goldsmith. Do you know him?

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: I know the man; what is the sum he owes?

speech.speaker: OFF.
speech.line: Two hundred ducats.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Say, how grows it due?

speech.speaker: OFF.
speech.line: Due for a chain your husband had of him.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: He did bespeak a chain for me, but had it not.

speech.speaker: COUR.
speech.line: When as your husband all in rage today
Came to my house, and took away my ring—
The ring I saw upon his finger now—
Straight after did I meet him with a chain.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: It may be so, but I did never see it.
Come, jailer, bring me where the goldsmith is,
I long to know the truth hereof at large.

scene.stagedir: Enter Antipholus of Syracuse, with his rapier drawn, and Dromio of Syracuse.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: God for thy mercy! They are loose again.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: And come with naked swords: let’s call more help
To have them bound again.

speech.speaker: OFF.
speech.line: Away, they’ll kill us.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt omnes but Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse as fast as may be, frighted.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: I see these witches are afraid of swords.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: She that would be your wife now ran from you.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: Come to the Centaur, fetch our stuff from thence;
I long that we were safe and sound aboard.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Faith, stay here this night, they will surely do us no harm. You saw they speak us fair, give us gold: methinks they are such a gentle nation that, but for the mountain of mad flesh that claims marriage of me, I could find in my heart to stay here still, and turn witch.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: I will not stay tonight for all the town:
Therefore away, to get our stuff aboard.

scene.scenepersonae: (Second Merchant, Angelo, Antipholus of Syracuse. Dromio of Syracuse, Adriana, Luciana, Courtezan, Lady Abbess, Duke of Ephesus, Egeon, Headsman, Officers, Messenger, Antipholus of Ephesus, Dromio of Ephesus)
scene.scenedescription: The merchant and Angelo, meeting Antipholus and Dromio of Syracuse, fight over the chain. Adriana, Luciana, the courtesan and others come, and Antipholus and Dromio take refuge in the priory, from whence the lady abbess refuses to deliver them. The Duke and Egeon enter, prepared for Egeon’s execution. A messenger brings tidings of the escape of Antipholus and Dromio of Ephesus, who have beaten up the servants and burnt Pinch’s beard. Antipholus and Dromio of Ephesus enter seeking justice against Adriana. The Duke tries to unravel the mystery of the conflicting testimonies. Egeon is denied by Antipholus and Dromio of Ephesus. The abbess enters with the other Antipholus and Dromio, and all is explained. It turns out that the Abbess is Egeon’s long-lost wife. The Duke pardons Egeon, and all ends well.
scene.stagedir: Enter the Second Merchant and Angelo the goldsmith.

speech.speaker: ANG.
speech.line: I am sorry, sir, that I have hind’red you,
But I protest he had the chain of me,
Though most dishonestly he doth deny it.

speech.speaker: 2. MER.
speech.line: How is the man esteem’d here in the city?

speech.speaker: ANG.
speech.line: Of very reverent reputation, sir,
Of credit infinite, highly belov’d,
Second to none that lives here in the city:
His word might bear my wealth at any time.

speech.speaker: 2. MER.
speech.line: Speak softly, yonder, as I think, he walks.

scene.stagedir: Enter Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse again.

speech.speaker: ANG.
speech.line: ’Tis so; and that self chain about his neck,
Which he forswore most monstrously to have.
Good sir, draw near to me, I’ll speak to him.
Signior Antipholus, I wonder much
That you would put me to this shame and trouble,
And, not without some scandal to yourself,
With circumstance and oaths so to deny
This chain which now you wear so openly.
Beside the charge, the shame, imprisonment,
You have done wrong to this my honest friend,
Who, but for staying on our controversy,
Had hoisted sail and put to sea today.
This chain you had of me, can you deny it?

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: I think I had, I never did deny it.

speech.speaker: 2. MER.
speech.line: Yes, that you did, sir, and forswore it too.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: Who heard me to deny it or forswear it?

speech.speaker: 2. MER.
speech.line: These ears of mine thou know’st did hear thee;
Fie on thee, wretch, ’tis pity that thou liv’st
To walk where any honest men resort.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: Thou art a villain to impeach me thus:
I’ll prove mine honor and mine honesty
Against thee presently, if thou dar’st stand.

speech.speaker: 2. MER.
speech.line: I dare, and do defy thee for a villain.

scene.stagedir: Enter Adriana, Luciana, Courtezan, and others.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Hold, hurt him not for God sake! He is mad.
Some get within him, take his sword away:
Bind Dromio too, and bear them to my house.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Run, master, run, for God’s sake take a house!
This is some priory, in, or we are spoil’d.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse to the priory.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: Be quiet, people. Wherefore throng you hither?

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: To fetch my poor distracted husband hence.
Let us come in, that we may bind him fast,
And bear him home for his recovery.

speech.speaker: ANG.
speech.line: I knew he was not in his perfect wits.

speech.speaker: 2. MER.
speech.line: I am sorry now that I did draw on him.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: How long hath this possession held the man?

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: This week he hath been heavy, sour, sad,
And much different from the man he was;
But till this afternoon his passion
Ne’er brake into extremity of rage.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: Hath he not lost much wealth by wrack of sea?
Buried some dear friend? Hath not else his eye
Stray’d his affection in unlawful love—
A sin prevailing much in youthful men,
Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing?
Which of these sorrows is he subject to?

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: To none of these, except it be the last,
Namely, some love that drew him oft from home.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: You should for that have reprehended him.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Why, so I did.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: Ay, but not rough enough.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: As roughly as my modesty would let me.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: Haply, in private.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: And in assemblies too.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: Ay, but not enough.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: It was the copy of our conference:
In bed he slept not for my urging it;
At board he fed not for my urging it;
Alone, it was the subject of my theme;
In company I often glanced it;
Still did I tell him it was vild and bad.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: And thereof came it that the man was mad.
The venom clamors of a jealous woman
Poisons more deadly than a mad dog’s tooth.
It seems his sleeps were hind’red by thy railing,
And thereof comes it that his head is light.
Thou say’st his meat was sauc’d with thy upbraidings:
Unquiet meals make ill digestions,
Thereof the raging fire of fever bred,
And what’s a fever but a fit of madness?
Thou say’st his sports were hind’red by thy brawls:
Sweet recreation barr’d, what doth ensue
But moody and dull melancholy,
Kinsman to grim and comfortless despair,
And at her heels a huge infectious troop
Of pale distemperatures and foes to life?
In food, in sport, and life-preserving rest
To be disturb’d, would mad or man or beast:
The consequence is then, thy jealous fits
Hath scar’d thy husband from the use of wits.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: She never reprehended him but mildly,
When he demean’d himself rough, rude, and wildly.
Why bear you these rebukes, and answer not?

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: She did betray me to my own reproof.
Good people, enter and lay hold on him.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: No, not a creature enters in my house.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Then let your servants bring my husband forth.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: Neither. He took this place for sanctuary,
And it shall privilege him from your hands
Till I have brought him to his wits again,
Or lose my labor in assaying it.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: I will attend my husband, be his nurse,
Diet his sickness, for it is my office,
And will have no attorney but myself,
And therefore let me have him home with me.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: Be patient, for I will not let him stir
Till I have us’d the approved means I have,
With wholesome syrups, drugs, and holy prayers,
To make of him a formal man again:
It is a branch and parcel of mine oath,
A charitable duty of my order,
Therefore depart, and leave him here with me.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: I will not hence, and leave my husband here;
And ill it doth beseem your holiness
To separate the husband and the wife.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: Be quiet and depart, thou shalt not have him.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Complain unto the Duke of this indignity.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Come go: I will fall prostrate at his feet,
And never rise until my tears and prayers
Have won his Grace to come in person hither,
And take perforce my husband from the abbess.

speech.speaker: 2. MER.
speech.line: By this I think the dial points at five.
Anon I’m sure the Duke himself in person
Comes this way to the melancholy vale,
The place of death and sorry execution,
Behind the ditches of the abbey here.

speech.speaker: ANG.
speech.line: Upon what cause?

speech.speaker: 2. MER.
speech.line: To see a reverent Syracusian merchant,
Who put unluckily into this bay
Against the laws and statutes of this town,
Beheaded publicly for his offense.

speech.speaker: ANG.
speech.line: See where they come, we will behold his death.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Kneel to the Duke before he pass the abbey.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Duke of Ephesus attended and Egeon the merchant of Syracuse, bare-head, with the Headsman and other Officers.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Yet once again proclaim it publicly,
If any friend will pay the sum for him,
He shall not die, so much we tender him.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Justice, most sacred Duke, against the abbess!

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: She is a virtuous and a reverend lady,
It cannot be that she hath done thee wrong.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: May it please your Grace, Antipholus my husband,
Who I made lord of me and all I had,
At your important letters—this ill day
A most outrageous fit of madness took him,
That desp’rately he hurried through the street—
With him his bondman, all as mad as he—
Doing displeasure to the citizens
By rushing in their houses, bearing thence
Rings, jewels, any thing his rage did like.
Once did I get him bound, and sent him home,
Whilst to take order for the wrongs I went,
That here and there his fury had committed.
Anon, I wot not by what strong escape,
He broke from those that had the guard of him,
And with his mad attendant and himself,
Each one with ireful passion, with drawn swords,
Met us again, and madly bent on us
Chas’d us away; till raising of more aid,
We came again to bind them. Then they fled
Into this abbey, whither we pursu’d them,
And here the abbess shuts the gates on us,
And will not suffer us to fetch him out,
Nor send him forth, that we may bear him hence.
Therefore, most gracious Duke, with thy command
Let him be brought forth, and borne hence for help.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Long since thy husband serv’d me in my wars,
And I to thee engag’d a prince’s word,
When thou didst make him master of thy bed,
To do him all the grace and good I could.
Go some of you, knock at the abbey-gate,
And bid the Lady Abbess come to me:
I will determine this before I stir.

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: O mistress, mistress, shift and save yourself!
My master and his man are both broke loose,
Beaten the maids a-row, and bound the doctor,
Whose beard they have sing’d off with brands of fire,
And ever as it blaz’d, they threw on him
Great pails of puddled mire to quench the hair;
My master preaches patience to him, and the while
His man with scissors nicks him like a fool;
And sure (unless you send some present help)
Between them they will kill the conjurer.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Peace, fool, thy master and his man are here,
And that is false thou dost report to us.

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: Mistress, upon my life, I tell you true;
I have not breath’d almost since I did see it.
He cries for you, and vows, if he can take you,
To scorch your face, and to disfigure you.
Hark, hark, I hear him, mistress; fly, be gone!

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Come stand by me, fear nothing. Guard with halberds!

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Ay me, it is my husband! Witness you,
That he is borne about invisible:
Even now we hous’d him in the abbey here,
And now he’s there, past thought of human reason.

scene.stagedir: Enter Antipholus of Ephesus and Dromio of Ephesus.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Justice, most gracious Duke, O, grant me justice,
Even for the service that long since I did thee,
When I bestrid thee in the wars, and took
Deep scars to save thy life; even for the blood
That then I lost for thee, now grant me justice.

speech.speaker: EGE.
speech.line: Unless the fear of death doth make me dote,
I see my son Antipholus and Dromio.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Justice, sweet prince, against that woman there!
She whom thou gav’st to me to be my wife;
That hath abused and dishonored me,
Even in the strength and height of injury:
Beyond imagination is the wrong
That she this day hath shameless thrown on me.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Discover how, and thou shalt find me just.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: This day, great Duke, she shut the doors upon me,
While she with harlots feasted in my house.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: A grievous fault! Say, woman, didst thou so?

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: No, my good lord. Myself, he, and my sister
Today did dine together: so befall my soul
As this is false he burdens me withal!

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Ne’er may I look on day, nor sleep on night,
But she tells to your Highness simple truth!

speech.speaker: ANG.
speech.line: O perjur’d woman! They are both forsworn:
In this the madman justly chargeth them.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: My liege, I am advised what I say,
Neither disturbed with the effect of wine,
Nor heady-rash, provok’d with raging ire,
Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad.
This woman lock’d me out this day from dinner;
That goldsmith there, were he not pack’d with her,
Could witness it, for he was with me then,
Who parted with me to go fetch a chain,
Promising to bring it to the Porpentine,
Where Balthazar and I did dine together.
Our dinner done, and he not coming thither,
I went to seek him. In the street I met him,
And in his company that gentleman.
There did this perjur’d goldsmith swear me down
That I this day of him receiv’d the chain,
Which, God he knows, I saw not; for the which
He did arrest me with an officer.
I did obey, and sent my peasant home
For certain ducats; he with none return’d.
Then fairly I bespoke the officer
To go in person with me to my house.
By th’ way we met
My wife, her sister, and a rabble more
Of vild confederates. Along with them
They brought one Pinch, a hungry lean-fac’d villain,
A mere anatomy, a mountebank,
A threadbare juggler and a fortune-teller,
A needy, hollow-ey’d, sharp-looking wretch,
A living dead man. This pernicious slave,
Forsooth, took on him as a conjurer,
And gazing in mine eyes, feeling my pulse,
And with no face, as ’twere, outfacing me,
Cries out, I was possess’d. Then all together
They fell upon me, bound me, bore me thence,
And in a dark and dankish vault at home
There left me and my man, both bound together,
Till gnawing with my teeth my bonds in sunder,
I gain’d my freedom; and immediately
Ran hither to your Grace, whom I beseech
To give me ample satisfaction
For these deep shames and great indignities.

speech.speaker: ANG.
speech.line: My lord, in truth, thus far I witness with him:
That he din’d not at home, but was lock’d out.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: But had he such a chain of thee, or no?

speech.speaker: ANG.
speech.line: He had, my lord, and when he ran in here,
These people saw the chain about his neck.

speech.speaker: 2. MER.
speech.line: Besides, I will be sworn these ears of mine
Heard you confess you had the chain of him,
After you first forswore it on the mart,
And thereupon I drew my sword on you;
And then you fled into this abbey here,
From whence I think you are come by miracle.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: I never came within these abbey walls,
Nor ever didst thou draw thy sword on me;
I never saw the chain, so help me heaven;
And this is false you burden me withal.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Why, what an intricate impeach is this!
I think you all have drunk of Circe’s cup.
If here you hous’d him, here he would have been;
If he were mad, he would not plead so coldly.
You say he din’d at home; the goldsmith here
Denies that saying. Sirrah, what say you?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Sir, he din’d with her there, at the Porpentine.

speech.speaker: COUR.
speech.line: He did, and from my finger snatch’d that ring.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: ’Tis true, my liege, this ring I had of her.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Saw’st thou him enter at the abbey here?

speech.speaker: COUR.
speech.line: As sure, my liege, as I do see your Grace.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Why, this is strange. Go call the abbess hither.
I think you are all mated, or stark mad.

speech.speaker: EGE.
speech.line: Most mighty Duke, vouchsafe me speak a word:
Haply I see a friend will save my life,
And pay the sum that may deliver me.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Speak freely, Syracusian, what thou wilt.

speech.speaker: EGE.
speech.line: Is not your name, sir, call’d Antipholus?
And is not that your bondman, Dromio?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Within this hour I was his bondman, sir,
But he, I thank him, gnaw’d in two my cords:
Now am I Dromio, and his man, unbound.

speech.speaker: EGE.
speech.line: I am sure you both of you remember me.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Ourselves we do remember, sir, by you;
For lately we were bound as you are now.
You are not Pinch’s patient, are you, sir?

speech.speaker: EGE.
speech.line: Why look you strange on me? You know me well.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: I never saw you in my life till now.

speech.speaker: EGE.
speech.line: O! Grief hath chang’d me since you saw me last,
And careful hours with time’s deformed hand
Have written strange defeatures in my face:
But tell me yet, dost thou not know my voice?

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Neither.

speech.speaker: EGE.
speech.line: Dromio, nor thou?

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: No, trust me, sir, nor I.

speech.speaker: EGE.
speech.line: I am sure thou dost!

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Ay, sir, but I am sure I do not—and whatsoever a man denies, you are now bound to believe him.

speech.speaker: EGE.
speech.line: Not know my voice! O time’s extremity,
Hast thou so crack’d and splitted my poor tongue
In seven short years, that here my only son
Knows not my feeble key of untun’d cares?
Though now this grained face of mine be hid
In sap-consuming winter’s drizzled snow,
And all the conduits of my blood froze up,
Yet hath my night of life some memory,
My wasting lamps some fading glimmer left,
My dull deaf ears a little use to hear:
All these old witnesses—I cannot err—
Tell me thou art my son Antipholus.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: I never saw my father in my life.

speech.speaker: EGE.
speech.line: But seven years since, in Syracuse, boy,
Thou know’st we parted, but perhaps, my son,
Thou sham’st to acknowledge me in misery.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: The Duke, and all that know me in the city,
Can witness with me that it is not so.
I ne’er saw Syracuse in my life.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: I tell thee, Syracusian, twenty years
Have I been patron to Antipholus,
During which time he ne’er saw Syracuse:
I see thy age and dangers make thee dote.

scene.stagedir: Enter the abbess with Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: Most mighty Duke, behold a man much wrong’d.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: I see two husbands, or mine eyes deceive me.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: One of these men is genius to the other:
And so of these, which is the natural man,
And which the spirit? Who deciphers them?

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: I, sir, am Dromio, command him away.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: I, sir, am Dromio, pray let me stay.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: Egeon art thou not? Or else his ghost?

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: O my old master, who hath bound him here?

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: Whoever bound him, I will loose his bonds,
And gain a husband by his liberty.
Speak, old Egeon, if thou be’st the man
That hadst a wife once call’d Aemilia,
That bore thee at a burden two fair sons.
O, if thou be’st the same Egeon, speak,
And speak unto the same Aemilia!

speech.speaker: EGE.
speech.line: If I dream not, thou art Aemilia.
If thou art she, tell me, where is that son
That floated with thee on the fatal raft?

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: By men of Epidamium he and I,
And the twin Dromio, all were taken up;
But by and by rude fishermen of Corinth
By force took Dromio and my son from them,
And me they left with those of Epidamium.
What then became of them I cannot tell;
I to this fortune that you see me in.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Why, here begins his morning story right:
These two Antipholus’, these two so like,
And these two Dromios, one in semblance—
Besides her urging of her wrack at sea—
These are the parents to these children,
Which accidentally are met together.
Antipholus, thou cam’st from Corinth first?

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: No, sir, not I, I came from Syracuse.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Stay, stand apart, I know not which is which.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: I came from Corinth, my most gracious lord—

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: And I with him.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Brought to this town by that most famous warrior,
Duke Menaphon, your most renowned uncle.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: Which of you two did dine with me today?

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: I, gentle mistress.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: And are not you my husband?

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: No, I say nay to that.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: And so do I, yet did she call me so;
And this fair gentlewoman, her sister here,
Did call me brother.
What I told you then
I hope I shall have leisure to make good,
If this be not a dream I see and hear.

speech.speaker: ANG.
speech.line: That is the chain, sir, which you had of me.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: I think it be, sir, I deny it not.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: And you, sir, for this chain arrested me.

speech.speaker: ANG.
speech.line: I think I did, sir, I deny it not.

speech.speaker: ADR.
speech.line: I sent you money, sir, to be your bail,
By Dromio, but I think he brought it not.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: No, none by me.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: This purse of ducats I receiv’d from you,
And Dromio my man did bring them me.
I see we still did meet each other’s man,
And I was ta’en for him, and he for me,
And thereupon these errors are arose.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: These ducats pawn I for my father here.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: It shall not need, thy father hath his life.

speech.speaker: COUR.
speech.line: Sir, I must have that diamond from you.

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: There take it, and much thanks for my good cheer.

speech.speaker: ABB.
speech.line: Renowned Duke, vouchsafe to take the pains
To go with us into the abbey here,
And hear at large discoursed all our fortunes;
And all that are assembled in this place
That by this sympathized one day’s error
Have suffer’d wrong, go keep us company,
And we shall make full satisfaction.
Thirty-three years have I but gone in travail
Of you, my sons, and till this present hour
My heavy burden ne’er delivered.
The Duke, my husband, and my children both,
And you the calendars of their nativity,
Go to a gossips’ feast, and go with me—
After so long grief, such nativity!

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: With all my heart, I’ll gossip at this feast.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt omnes. Manent the two Dromios and two brothers.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Master, shall I fetch your stuff from shipboard?

speech.speaker: E. ANT.
speech.line: Dromio, what stuff of mine hast thou embark’d?

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Your goods that lay at host, sir, in the Centaur.

speech.speaker: S. ANT.
speech.line: He speaks to me. I am your master, Dromio.
Come go with us, we’ll look to that anon.
Embrace thy brother there, rejoice with him.

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: There is a fat friend at your master’s house,
That kitchen’d me for you today at dinner:
She now shall be my sister, not my wife.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Methinks you are my glass, and not my brother:
I see by you I am a sweet-fac’d youth.
Will you walk in to see their gossiping?

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: Not I, sir, you are my elder.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: That’s a question; how shall we try it?

speech.speaker: S. DRO.
speech.line: We’ll draw cuts for the senior, till then, lead thou first.

speech.speaker: E. DRO.
speech.line: Nay then thus:
We came into the world like brother and brother;
And now let’s go hand in hand, not one before another.
